paragraphs.text: %md # Tutorial 4c Getting Started with Oracle Data Visualization Desktop This tutorial was built for BDCS-CE version 17.3.5-20 as part of the New Data Lake User Journey: here. Questions and feedback about the tutorial: Note: Please complete the tutorial "Adding more datasets" before attempting this one as you will need the hive table bike_trips_weather_parquet to continue

msg.data:
Tutorial 4c Getting Started with Oracle Data Visualization Desktop

This tutorial was built for BDCS-CE version 17.3.5-20 as part of the New Data Lake User Journey: here. Questions and feedback about the tutorial: david.bayard@oracle.com

Note: Please complete the tutorial "Adding more datasets" before attempting this one as you will need the hive table bike_trips_weather_parquet to continue

paragraphs.text: %md # About Oracle Data Visualization Desktop Oracle Data Visualization Desktop ( here ) is a lightweight, single-file download tool to easily analyze data. Data Visualization Desktop can connect to a variety of data sources. In this tutorial, we will show you how to install DV Desktop, connect it to BDCS-CE, and start to build visualizations on our Bike Trip dataset.

msg.data:
About Oracle Data Visualization Desktop

Oracle Data Visualization Desktop ( here ) is a lightweight, single-file download tool to easily analyze data. Data Visualization Desktop can connect to a variety of data sources. In this tutorial, we will show you how to install DV Desktop, connect it to BDCS-CE, and start to build visualizations on our Bike Trip dataset.

paragraphs.text: %md # Download Oracle Data Visualization Desktop Download DV Desktop from here This tutorial is based on DVD version 12.2.3.0.0 - June 2017 Update. You need to be at least on this version. ![DVDownload](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/oracle/learning-library/master/workshops/journey2-new-data-lake/images/300/snap0012145.jpg "DVDownload")

msg.data:
Download Oracle Data Visualization Desktop

Download DV Desktop from here

This tutorial is based on DVD version 12.2.3.0.0 - June 2017 Update. You need to be at least on this version.

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Extract the DV Desktop zip file and run the DVDesktop.msi

+ Unzip the file you downloaded to extract the .msi file, and then launch the .msi file.
![DVInstall](https://gse00010212.storage.oraclecloud.com/v1/Storage-gse00010212/images/snap0011606.jpg "DVInstall")

+ Follow the prompts to install DV Desktop

+ When the install is done, click Finish
![DVInstall2](https://gse00010212.storage.oraclecloud.com/v1/Storage-gse00010212/images/snap0011607.jpg "DVInstall2")

+ DV Desktop will launch
![DVInstall3](https://gse00010212.storage.oraclecloud.com/v1/Storage-gse00010212/images/snap0011608.jpg "DVInstall3")

msg.data:
Extract the DV Desktop zip file and run the DVDesktop.msi

  • Unzip the file you downloaded to extract the .msi file, and then launch the .msi file.

  • Follow the prompts to install DV Desktop

  • When the install is done, click Finish

  • DV Desktop will launch

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Configuring the Spark Thrift server on BDCS-CE

As of BDCS-CE 17.3.5 and DV Desktop 3.0, you will need to change some of the settings on the Spark Thrift server to connect properly.

**Please follow the instructions in the "xtra Connecting DV Desktop and Spark" notebook.  Then return here and continue.**

msg.data:
Configuring the Spark Thrift server on BDCS-CE

As of BDCS-CE 17.3.5 and DV Desktop 3.0, you will need to change some of the settings on the Spark Thrift server to connect properly.

Please follow the instructions in the “xtra Connecting DV Desktop and Spark” notebook. Then return here and continue.

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Connecting to the HiveServer2 port

Now, you need to decide how you want to connect to the Hive Thrift Server port, which you set to port 10002.  You can either choose to use a SSH tunnel (which is very secure) or choose to open port 10002 to the outside world (which can be less secure).

+ If you want to use a SSH tunnel, refer to the note "xtra Connecting to Ambari" which has an example of setting up a SSH tunnel (but you would use port 10002 instead of Ambari's 8080).
+ If you want to open up port 10002, you will need to create a new access rule for port 10002.  Refer to the note "xtra Connecting via SSH" or "OEHCS Tutorial 1" for examples of working with network access rules.

msg.data:
Connecting to the HiveServer2 port

Now, you need to decide how you want to connect to the Hive Thrift Server port, which you set to port 10002. You can either choose to use a SSH tunnel (which is very secure) or choose to open port 10002 to the outside world (which can be less secure).

  • If you want to use a SSH tunnel, refer to the note “xtra Connecting to Ambari” which has an example of setting up a SSH tunnel (but you would use port 10002 instead of Ambari’s 8080).
  • If you want to open up port 10002, you will need to create a new access rule for port 10002. Refer to the note “xtra Connecting via SSH” or “OEHCS Tutorial 1” for examples of working with network access rules.

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Define a connection in DV Desktop for the Hive connection

+ Open up DV Desktop
+ Click on Data Sources
+ Click on Connection (Under Create)
+ Click on Hortonworks Hive
+ Enter the Connection Name
+ Enter the Hostname.  If you chose to use SSH tunneling, enter "127.0.0.1" for the hostname.  If you chose to open port 10002 to the outside, enter the hostname or ip address of your BDCS-CE server.
+ Enter to port, which is 10002
+ Set the Username to hive
+ Set the Password to x

![DVDconnection](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/millerhoo/journey2-new-data-lake/master/workshops/journey2-new-data-lake/images/300/DVDconnection.gif)

msg.data:
Define a connection in DV Desktop for the Hive connection

  • Open up DV Desktop
  • Click on Data Sources
  • Click on Connection (Under Create)
  • Click on Hortonworks Hive
  • Enter the Connection Name
  • Enter the Hostname. If you chose to use SSH tunneling, enter “127.0.0.1” for the hostname. If you chose to open port 10002 to the outside, enter the hostname or ip address of your BDCS-CE server.
  • Enter to port, which is 10002
  • Set the Username to hive
  • Set the Password to x

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Create a DV Desktop Data Source for your connection

+ Double click on your Connection
+ Double click on the default database
+ Double click on the bike_trips_small table
+ Click on Add All
+ Now click on the rightmost icon in the dataflow pipeline (it will be the icon after the filter icon). Then, click on the Refresh property. Change this to be “Live - Always use the database”. **NOTE: This step is not yet captured in the screenshot below**
+ Click on Add
+ Click Create Project

![DVDdatasource](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/millerhoo/journey2-new-data-lake/master/workshops/journey2-new-data-lake/images/300/DVDdatasource.gif "HODBC")

msg.data:
Create a DV Desktop Data Source for your connection

  • Double click on your Connection
  • Double click on the default database
  • Double click on the bike_trips_small table
  • Click on Add All
  • Now click on the rightmost icon in the dataflow pipeline (it will be the icon after the filter icon). Then, click on the Refresh property. Change this to be “Live - Always use the database”. NOTE: This step is not yet captured in the screenshot below
  • Click on Add
  • Click Create Project

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Create a visualization in your project

+ Right-click on My Calculations.. choose Add Calculation..
+ Expand Aggregate and double-click on Count(*)
+ Name the calculation "num_trips"
+ Click Save
+ Right-click on num_trips and choose Create Best Visualization
+ Drag Usertype to the Category (Y-Axis) area
+ Drag Gender to the Color area

![DVDvisualize](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/millerhoo/journey2-new-data-lake/master/workshops/journey2-new-data-lake/images/300/DVDvisualize.gif)

msg.data:
Create a visualization in your project

  • Right-click on My Calculations.. choose Add Calculation..
  • Expand Aggregate and double-click on Count(*)
  • Name the calculation “num_trips”
  • Click Save
  • Right-click on num_trips and choose Create Best Visualization
  • Drag Usertype to the Category (Y-Axis) area
  • Drag Gender to the Color area

Run the following shell paragraph to see the recent SQL commands sent to the Hive Server.

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Tip - Viewing the DVD log files

+ Navigate to where you installed DVD (example: c:\Program Files\Data Visualization Desktop)
+ Open up a CMD window as Administrator in that folder
+ In the CMD window, type:
    diagnostic_dump.cmd outputfile.zip
+ Look in the outputfile.zip for the logs
 
Or look at C:\Users\USERNAME\AppData\Local\Temp\DVDesktop\logs\OBIS\obis1-query.log

msg.data:
Tip - Viewing the DVD log files

  • Navigate to where you installed DVD (example: c:\Program Files\Data Visualization Desktop)
  • Open up a CMD window as Administrator in that folder
  • In the CMD window, type:
    diagnostic_dump.cmd outputfile.zip
  • Look in the outputfile.zip for the logs

Or look at C:\Users\USERNAME\AppData\Local\Temp\DVDesktop\logs\OBIS\obis1-query.log
